src_text: Sundarbans ke sone sekgwa se se pataganeng sa ditlhare tsa mangrove tse di bapisitseng lewatle, se se di fetang tsotlhe mo lefatsheng. Se boleele ja dikhilomithara di le masome a marobedi (80), mme se ralela lefatshe la Bangladesh le la Intia go tswa ko lewatleng.
ref_text: The Sundarbans are the largest littoral mangrove belt in the world, stretching 80 km (50 mi) into the Bangladeshi and Indian hinterland from the coast.
hyp_text: The Sundarbans is a mangrove forest located in the delta region of Padma, Brahmaputra and Meghna rivers on the Bay of Bengal. It covers an area of 10,000 km2 (3,900 sq mi), 60% of which is in Bangladesh. The forest is intersected by a complex network of tidal waterways, mudflats and small islands of salt-tolerant mangrove forests, and covers an area of 10,000 km2 (3,900 sq mi), 6,000 km2 (2,300 sq mi) of which is in Bangladesh. The Sundarbans is the largest single block of tidal halophytic (salt-loving) mangrove forest in the world. The forest area, now much fragmented, is about 6,000 km2 (2,300 sq mi) in Bangladesh and 4,110 km2 (1,590 sq mi) in India. The forest lies in the extreme southern part of the country, covering 38 of the total 64 districts of Bangladesh, with the majority of the forest in the Khulna Division, including Bagerhat, Satkhira, and Khulna districts. The forest has been declared a core protected area of Bangladesh and is the largest mangrove forest in the world.
